This is constructive criticism. Please accept it that way. There are severa=
l issues with your code, in addition to answering your original question.

=
1. Your comments are useless and actually dangerous. I say this with love. =
Stop writing silly comments when the code says exactly what it does already=
.

EXAMPLE:
>     // This member variable will hold account balance
>     p=
ublic int balance;

The following is already clear enough.

>     public in=
t balance;

You may ask why this matters. Here is why. In your code you hav=
e:

>public class Interest extends Account {
>     
>     // This member va=
riable will hold account balance
>     private int interest_rate;
>     pri=
vate int acumulated_interest;

THAT COMMENT IS WRONG!

You have just demons=
trated the reason why unnecessary comments are not just unnecessary, they a=
re DANGEROUS: your comment and code do not match. Three months from now, wh=
ich one should you trust? At a minimum, you need to read the code to find o=
ut.

Stop doing this immediately. You will find life much nicer.

2. Use be=
tter names.

"JU" means nothing to anyone, except maybe yourself. I renamed=
 the test case classes to "AccountTest" and "InterestTest", because THAT IS=
 WHAT THEY ARE!

3. Don't leave empty tests.

You have an empty test in Acc=
ountTest. That test LOOKS like it passes, but only because there is nothing=
 to fail. I replaced it with "fail("Not yet implemented.")".

4. One of you=
r tests doesn't make sense.

deposit() answers the new balance, but withdra=
w() answers the amount withdrawn. Why have this strange behavior?

    publ=
ic void testwithdraw2() {
        assertEquals(myAccount.withdraw(4000), 40=
00);
    } //End of method

I changed this test to read

    public void te=
stwithdraw2() {
        assertEquals(myAccount.withdraw(4000), 6000);
    }=


because this behavior makes much more sense, compared with the behavior o=
f deposit().

I ran AccountTest. Of the three tests that you implemented, t=
wo passed, so I fixed withdraw() to behave the same way as deposit().

I th=
en ran InterestTest. Of the five tests that you implemented, they all pass.=


Since you got the inheritance stuff right, what's the problem?

>So said =
balakrishnan sengodan on 4/13/2003 --------------------
>Did any one test i=
nheritance successfully, will you
>please send me the classes under the tes=
t and the
>associated testing classes. 
<snip />

J. B. Rainsberger,

ent, Diaspar Software Services
